Dr. King gifted us a radical dream & a disruptive blueprint for change.

I'm committed to following that blueprint & to the liberation of my people.

That means organizing & mobilizing, legislating our values, centering healing & humanity in our policymaking & leading with love.

Gains are not guarantees when inertia, inaction & insurrection thrive.

Gains are not guarantees when the white moderate is complicit in white supremacy.

There is no room for compromise when it comes to guaranteeing all Americans the right to vote, and there should be no room in a democracy for those who want to deny voting rights and overturn election results.
MLK taught the nation that when it comes to basic civil rights there is no room for compromise ‚Äì and that remains true today.

Dr. King, with Congressman Lewis beside him, fought for the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, and Congressman Lewis fought until his death to restore the Voting Rights Act after it was gutted by the Supreme Court in 2013.

I think it‚Äôs important to begin today by recognizing the awkward reality: across the country we are seeing elected officials who refuse to support the John R. Lewis Act celebrate the memory of Dr. King.

Dr. King warned us about this in 1957.

And so let me say this. In 2022, we must commit ourselves to a politics that is unabashedly committed to racial justice in the face of lies, hatred, and propaganda.

They tell us to slow up. We're telling them they need to catch up.

This Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. day feels different.

Voting rights. Teaching the truth about our history. The treatment of Black migrants at our border. The lack of action on ending police violence.

His legacy is being taken for granted.

"We call for a liberalism [...] which will be thoroughly committed to the ideal of racial justice and will not be deterred by the propaganda and subtle words of those who say: ‚ÄòSlow up for a while; you‚Äôre pushing too fast.‚Äô‚Äù

"It is a liberalism so bent on seeing all sides, that it fails to become committed to either side. 

It is a liberalism that is so objectively analytical that it is not subjectively committed. 

It is a liberalism which is neither hot nor cold, but lukewarm...

"There is a dire need today for a liberalism which is truly liberal. 

What we are witnessing today [...] is a sort of quasi-liberalism which is based on the principle of looking sympathetically at all sides...

I'm going to share an excerpt from Dr. King's "Give Us the Ballot" speech in 1957.

I want you to read it. And truly let it sink in.

Then remember it next time someone says that our movement for justice needs to slow down, or be quiet, or wait our turn.

The Voting Rights Act of 1965, and the subsequent increase in Black voting, was followed by increases in state public spending. 

Nearly half of that increase was directed toward education and resulted in improved outcomes for students. https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w17776/w17776.pdf 3/

Evidence finds the Voting Rights Act reduced the Black-white wage gap by about 5.5 percentage points between 1950 and 1980.

Since the Supreme Court rolled back voter protections in 2013, there's already evidence of a reversal of this progress. https://equitablegrowth.org/voting-rights-equal-economic-progress-the-voting-rights-act-and-u-s-economic-inequality/ 2/

As we honor the legacy of Dr. King this #MLK day, we are reminded of the interconnectedness of protecting voting rights and addressing economic inequality. 

Evidence shows improving voter protections lifts wages, school quality and employment.
